Posts.Content: Hi! I will offer my opinion--I once did the "watch and wait" routine, and, believe me when I tell you this, but every day of those 6 long months, I worried about the cluster of calcifications in my breast, all day and night. At the end of the six months, nothing had really changed in the mammo, but I couldn't bear going through another day wondering and had the biopsy. It was benign, and I was so happy and relieved that it was over. It is not an easy time. Perhaps they can do a simple needle biopsy under the mammo. I had 2 done this year, and I had the results in an hour. Good luck, sweetie! I am here if you have any further questions.
Posts.Title: BIOPSY or WAIT 6 MONTHS??

Posts.Content: Hi! After my diagnosis of LCIS, my doctor put me on Evista which is also an estrogen blocker. I developed the symptoms that you are experiencing on the Tamoxifen which she felt, was due to too much estrogen being blocked. She then switched me to tamoxifen. I did not experience that side effect with tamoxifen. The bottom line of what I am explaining is that you have to talk to your doctor who prescribed the medication and tell her what you are feeling. There are other estrogen blockers that may not give you that side effect. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Question for anyone on Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: I also have had quite a few needle biopsies that have shown atypical cells that "were on the verge of turning to cancer." I had surgical lumpectomies following the diagnosis. The first time, they discovered that I have LCIS which increases my chances for cancer. The rest have all been benign. They way that I have looked at this is that I am happy that they have all been benign, even though I had to go through the stress and the surgery. I would not take the chance of leaving even one of those abnormal cells in my breast that could turn into cancer. You have to have a different spin on this. Instead of thinking of it as a unnessary waste of time, think of it that you are being proactive in saving your life.
Posts.Title: confused about diagnosis and suggested treatment

Posts.Content: I am glad that you are going to see the doctor. I hope that you are fine and that your check-up will give you peace of mind. Good luck, sweetie, and please post with your results!
Posts.Title: Both Breasts enlarged some other symptoms

Posts.Content: Kimmie, I don't have any advice, but I do think you are doing the right thing just your peace of mind. i will say a prayer that everything works out well for you! Good luck, sweetie!
Posts.Title: Odd bruising on breast that won't go away 1 2

Posts.Content: So happy to hear your good news! Go out and celebrate!
Posts.Title: Odd bruising on breast that won't go away 1 2

Posts.Content: The problem that I had was that I had a cluster of many calcifications that were overlapping each other. Each appeared to be smooth and round-a usually benign sign. But I had many of them clustered together. The radiologist thought we should wait and see if there was any change in 6months. My doctor thought it was safe to wait also and see. I went along with their opinion. But I worried about was under that cluster--how about the ones they couldn't see? I worried that maybe a change was taking place during that time, and, if I had acted sooner, it could still have been benign. Those were the thoughts that went around and around in my mind. After 6 months, they were the same. I could have watched and waited another 6 months, but I couldn't take the stress of it anymore, so I opted to have it removed. I didn't want to wait to hear the words, "Well, it has changed. Now it has to be biopsied." A biopsy done in the mammo dept. is easy and fast. It does not require general anesthesia. I have had them done under a mammo, ultrasound, and even an MRI machine. The radiologist injects the area with a local anesthesia, and then takes a sample out of the area. I had two done this past Feb. Unfortunately, mine came out with abnormal cells, and I then had to have a surgical biopsy (benign). Please keep me posted, and good luck to you!
Posts.Title: BIOPSY or WAIT 6 MONTHS??

Posts.Content: Hi Harmony, I was diagnosed in 1998 with LCIS. I have had many biopsies with abnormal findings. I also am so afraid of the time when I will have a cancer diagnosis. I think because of my LCIS diagnosis and your diagnosis, they take extra precautions when we have our mammographies. I think that what may have appeared on your mammogram looked like a cyst on the ultrasound. Your doctor will have the reports and he will go over them with you. Believe me---if it looked like anything had the potential of being malignant, you would be headed for a biopsy, and not waiting for a year. Talk to your doctor, and then go out to celebrate!!! Love to you!
Posts.Title: Total nightmare

Posts.Content: Hi Harmoney, To begin with your doctor has to order the MRI. Then you have to find out if your insurance will cover it. Many do not cover it. From what I understand, MRIs are very sensitive and pick up any little piece of "junk" that is in your breast. Let me tell you my experience. Three years ago, I had had a mammo and and ultrasound. Both were negative. Because of my history, the radiologist recommended a baseline MRI. My insurance co. approved it. I had the MRI and it showed a small area of "junk." That is what my doctor called it. No one knew what it was so I had a biopsy under the MRI. The pathology showed cells that were so abnormal that they were on the verge of turning malignant. The pathologist was afraid that some of the cells may not have been removed and that they may have turned malignant so I had a surgical lumpectomy. My pathology for that was a benign papilloma. I have to believe that the MRI saved me because those cells would have been malignant by the time I had my next mammo. I also believe that they must have gotten all the cells in the first biopsy. My doctor does not commit himself and says "who knows what would happen. Maybe they would just stay abnormal and benign, or they could have turned malignant." So I don't know if my story helps or not. You have to trust your doctor and let him decide if he feels you should have one. If he does, make sure you go to a place that has a wide MRI where you go in feet first. My first one was a head in first and it was scary. The other one when I had the biopsy was done in a hospital, and I went in feet first--it made so much of a difference. Please keep me posted and good luck!
Posts.Title: Total nightmare

Posts.Content: Hi! I also had a stereotatic biopsy that came out highly atypical, but benign. The doctor who did the biopsy explained that it is important to have a wide surgical excision done because it is crucial that all the atypical cells are removed. Atypical cells can turn malignant even though they are in the benign stage now. You would not want to leave any of those cells in there. The surgeon will do a wide excision-which means that he will cut out the area until he gets a clean margin. In my case--the cells in the biopsy were highly atypical which meant that they were on the verge of changing over to malignant. The doctor was afraid that possibly a few cells could have turned. The final biopsy on the wide excision was totally benign--they had gotten most of the cells in the stereotatic!! I hope that you turn out the same. Please write to me if you have any questions!! You will be fine!
Posts.Title: stereotactic now excisional biopsy question please 1 2

Posts.Content: Quote: Originally Posted by sweetpeas6 Dear Nibbsie I saw your previous answer to Chis and I was hoping you could give me some information. In 2006 I had microcalcifications that I had a Stero biopsy that was benign. Every year since I have had a normal mamogram. This year it showed new, clustered microcalcifications. The radiologist said they looked different. They are very small even with the magnifying glass. He said that there was a 70-75% that they were normal but if it was something this would be what I would want because it was small and slow. He said I didn't have to make up my mind then about the biopsy (but he didn't say how long I could wait) but I made an appointment to have it done right away. What do you think my chances are since he said they were different? If I have to have a lumpectomy what is invloved? Could this be early stage breast cancer and is there usually a good outcome to it? Thank you so much for your response. Sweetpea HI Sweetpea, I know what it is like to be nervous and upset by a mamogram. I have had biopsies for clustered microcalcifications quite a few times, and, fortunately, have turned out to be papillomas which are benign. My LCIS diagnosis was an incidental finding that occurred during one of these surgeries. My atypical hyperplasia was found on an MRI and not seen on a mamo or a sonogram. Did the radiologist tell you what was different about these calcifications? Is it that the numbers have increased in the cluster? A good sign is that he is not rushing you to have them removed. One time, I was told to come back in 6 months to see if there was a change. Those 6 months were so difficult for me because I worried day and night about what was going on. When I went back for a mamo then, the radiologist wanted a biopsy done because the numbers had increased even more. That one was also a papilloma. How I wished I had had it done 6 months earlier because it would have saved me so much anxiety!! You are doing the right thing having it done now and not putting it off. I wish you good luck. If you have any questions, please write me! I am sending you good thoughts for a great outcome!
Posts.Title: stereotactic now excisional biopsy question please 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi! I know you are nervous, but the best thing is to get all this checked out by your doctor. I have had lumps under my arms before also from ingrown hairs. What I have learned through all this is not to touch them all the time--all you do is aggravate them. I know it is hard not to check them, but just try! They may go away quicker that way if they are caused by ingrown hairs, shaving or deodorant. I wish you luck and send you good wishes and thoughts that these lumps are nothing! Go see your doctor soon so you can move on with your life! Love to you!
Posts.Title: Lump in Armpit

Posts.Content: So happy to hear your good news! Now enjoy the holidays!!
Posts.Title: "asymmetric" mammogram result

Posts.Content: Harmony--Did anyone talk to you after the mammography or the ultrasound? Do you have any idea about what they saw? I have been in the same position as this many times having many extra films taken and many "zooming" in on one spot. Sometimes it does show something that needs a biopsy or a "watch for 6 months," or other times, it is because they thought they saw something, there was a fold, or some other benign reason. Lets hope for the best! Saying a prayer for you! Carm
Posts.Title: Total nightmare

Posts.Content: Hello, I would like to tell you my experience. Thirty years ago, while nursing my fourth child, I also felt 3 lumps in my breast-two in one and one in the other. I thought at first they were clogged milk ducts, but I soon realized they were not. I went to see my ob, who called the hospital, asked if there was a surgeon available, and sent me right to the emergency room! I was so afraid! The doctor reassured me, and withdrew 3 vials of fluid (one vial from each lump) and sent them off to be biopsied. A few days later, he called me and told me they were benign cysts! I also agree with Sharon--you need a biopsy to put your mind at ease. Hopefully, you will have the same outcome that I had! Good luck!
Posts.Title: 27yrs old: grape size lump: breastfeeding

Posts.Content: Quote: Originally Posted by Cowpin8 Misty800: Do you mind if I ask you, Did you have this procedure yourself? If so, can you give me some details and what to expect? Did you have a complex cyst also? How did you recover and was it a success? How long were you in pain afterwards, etc... I am really nervous over this wire in my breast thing. Thank You, Joe. Hi, I have had this procedure done at least 3 times. Are you having it done under a mamo, ultrasound, or MRI? I have had it done under a mamo and MRI, and I think the procedure is the same for all of them. You are sitting in a chair. They locate the area that needs to be biopsied. The numb the area, and then the radiologist inserts a very thin wire into it to identify the spot for the surgeon. The wire is so thin that you can't feel it once it is inserted. Then they wheel you up to the operating room. The surgery is about an hour long, from the start to finish. You then go recovery for a short time. They wake you up, and as soon as you feel ok, you go home. Remember to ask the surgeon how the area looked, what does he think--questions like that--he can give you an indication, but not a precise answer. I was never in much pain. I think one time I took 2 tylenols, but that was it. I got my results about 2 days later. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: stereotactic now excisional biopsy question please 1 2

Posts.Content: I think you need to see your doctor for this. There is a condition called inflammatory breast cancer that starts as a rash. I am not saying that you have this, but that diagnosis needs to be eliminated. I have run many times with things that turn out to be a fungus infection, but I think it is better to be safe than sorry. Good luck, sweetie, and don't let this go.
Posts.Title: Scaly, oozing rash on areola that won't go away...

Posts.Content: Hi! I was diagnosed with LCIS (I believe is now being called lobular neoplasm) in 1998. At the time, many doctors were using Evista as a substitute for Tamoxifen because it had less side effects. I took it for a year and had a horrible time. I gained weight, had headaches, and terrible joint pain. I then was switched to Tamoxifen mainly because American Cancer said it was the choice drug for LCIS. I have to tell you, I had no side effects. In fact, I was sad to have to go off it when my 5 years were up! It is thought that taking these drugs after 5 years increases the breast cancer risk rather than decreasing it! Last year, I had another lumpectomy for severe atypia, and the good news was that I had minimal LCIS. My doctor said that it was the result of the tamoxifen, and that it did its job. Good luck! Carm
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen or Aromatase Inhibitor?? Which is Better?

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear about your mom, Pat. My deepest condolences to you and your family.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: I think the worst part of this journey is the waiting. Two months passed between my mammo, breast mri, biopsy, and then excisional biopsy. I did not have much pain after the wide resection. I had to wear a pressure bra for the first week which they gave me in the hospital. I asked for an additional one to bring home because you have to wear it all the time, and I was able to wash one, wear one. I also have LCIS besides atypical cells which was diagnosed 11 years ago. I did 5 years of tamoxifen following that diagnosis. My friend, who also has atypical cells, also took tamoxifen for 5 years. Since you will now be considered high risk, you may want to think of some type of medication. You can ask your surgeon after this is over if you are a candidate. Good luck to you, sweetie. I am here if you have more questions. Carm
Posts.Title: stereotactic now excisional biopsy question please 1 2

Posts.Content: Quote: Originally Posted by Cowpin8 I am new to this topic. I am a 40-year old MALE. Today I found out that I have a 5 mm complex cyst in my left breast. I have been having pretty bad pain in my left chest, so 6 months ago I had a mammogram. It showed nothing. Then I had a Breast MRI. It also showed nothing. I started to think I was going crazy because the chest pain was getting worse. So last week I went for a breast sonogram. BINGO... The radiologist said I have a 5mm complex cyst at the 2 oclock position in my left beast. BIRADS category 3. I am VERY happy that they found what was wrong. My question is, What do I do now? I am a male, so this subject is new to me. Thanks, Joe. What did the radiologist recommend? Did you have the results sent to your Primary Care physician? Your doctor will probably want you to see a breast surgeon who may want to drain or remove the cyst and biopsy the fluid it contains. Speak to your doctor and follow his advice. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: stereotactic now excisional biopsy question please 1 2

Posts.Content: I am hoping that you will hear soon, and that you will have good news!! I will be thinking of you. Good luck, sweetie. Love to you!
Posts.Title: stereotactic now excisional biopsy question please 1 2

Posts.Content: Hope everything went well! Please let us know how you did! Good luck!
Posts.Title: stereotactic now excisional biopsy question please 1 2

Posts.Content: So happy to hear your good news! Go out and celebrate!
Posts.Title: My breast cancer scare (Lump found Birad 4)

Posts.Content: Try putting warm, wet compresses on it about 3 times a day. Wet a wash cloth with warm water, wring it out, and lay it on top of the area. When it gets cool, wring it out with more warm water. Do that for about twenty minutes. This helps the bacteria to come to a head and drain. Once it starts to drain, continue the soaks and wash the area with an antibacterial soap like Dial etc., to keep it clean. It is important that you wash your hands before and after doing the soaks and keeping the area as clean as possible. If you don't see an improvement then you need to see a doctor. I hope that this helps.
Posts.Title: Breast Lump/Pimple

Posts.Content: I am so sorry that you are going through this. I have not had a cyst with blood in it, so I cannot give you any advice about my experience. But what I can share with you is the anxiety and apprehension that you are going through. This experience is so hard. I see that you are having the surgery tomorrow. Having had quite a few biopsies, I have learned to ask the surgeon after the surgery for his/her opinion. They can usually tell you their gut feeling from what they saw and felt during the operation. Please don't be afraid. The surgery is not hard. I have had wire localization done first in the radiology department. Then you go on to the operating room where you are given an IV with medication which puts you to sleep. The whole thing takes about one hour. As soon as you are fully awake, you go home. I had minimal pain and only took tylenol. I did have to wear a pressure bra for a week. The worse part of the whole thing is the stress and anxiety ahead of time. For some reason, I felt better after the surgery because the thing was out of my body. Please write me back if you have any questions. I wish you luck, and I will say a prayer for you! Good luck, sweetie! Carm
Posts.Title: Ultrasound Showed Blood in Breast Cyst

Posts.Content: Sarah, I am soooooo happy to hear from you! I was thinking of you for the past 2 days and hoping all went well for you. The waiting is the worst part. I hope this time goes quickly for you. Try to keep yourself busy. There was always a weekend involved when I was waiting for biopsy results. For some reason, I was calmer because I knew that no one would be calling me with results on the weekend so I didn't need to stress out each time the phone rang! Take care of yourself, sweetie. I am thinking of you and saying prayers! Love to you! Carm
Posts.Title: Ultrasound Showed Blood in Breast Cyst

Posts.Content: I am so happy for you, sweetie!!! Go out and celebrate! Love to you. Carm
Posts.Title: Ultrasound Showed Blood in Breast Cyst

Posts.Content: I think that this means that all the DCIS was gotten during the stereotactic biopsy, and that is why none remained in the lumpectomy. Take it as a good sign that the amount of DCIS was minimal. Good luck to you, sweetie!
Posts.Title: DCIS and Lobular Neoplasia

Posts.Content: Hi! Last year, I had a similar experience as you. I had a small area show up on a breast MRI that was not seen on a mammography or ultrasound. I had a stereotactic biopsy done under the MRI which showed severe atypia-cells that were benign, but were about to turn malignant. The radiologist called me and told me that I needed a wide excision breast biopsy as soon as possible to make sure that all the cells had been removed. She also called my breast surgeon and told him the same thing. I had the surgery, and, thankfully, the area was also benign. I think the radiologist wants to make sure all the abnormal cells have been removed and that you have wide, clean margins to insure that none of the cells have been left . Any cells that could be left in that area that are different could eventually turn to cancer. I would also suggest that you speak to your breast surgeon about the estrogen replacement. Because of previous diagnosis of atypical cells and LCIS, I took tamoxifen for 5 years. Tamoxifen is an estrogen blocker. In some women, breast cancer is fueled by estrogen, and taking an estrogen replacement is not good. You need to get advice about that. I want to tell you that the surgery was not bad. It was same day--I was in the hospital for a total of about 8 hours. I had very little pain and only needed a tylenol for discomfort!! I wish you luck, and if you have any questions, please ask!! Good luck, sweetie-you will be fine!
Posts.Title: Confused about atypical cells found during needle biopsy

Posts.Content: I am so glad to hear from you. I am sorry that this is taking so long, and that you are going through the torment of not knowing. It is sooo hard. I don't understand the long wait, but I am glad you called the doctor. Maybe they are now checking on it, and you will hear shortly! Or you could call the office back in the morning, and explain how nervous you are, and if they could check for the results??? I know you will hear good news, and I hope you hear it soon!! Love to you!
Posts.Title: Ultrasound Showed Blood in Breast Cyst

Posts.Content: Hi! I also took tamoxifen for 5 years (1999-2004) for preventative purposes due to a diagnosis of atypical hyperplasia and LCIS. My main side effects were the hot flashes. Two years ago, I had a surgical biopsy of a suspicious area in my breast, which, thankfully, was benign. My breast surgeon told me that the pathology showed a marked decrease in the LCIS, which he felt was due to the 5 years of tamoxifen. In my case, the tamoxifen did its job!! Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: I know that you are so afraid. I have been there and understand. I want to wish you luck, and tell you that I will be thinking of you and praying that all will go well for you. Please write back and tell me how your appointment went. Love to you. Carm
Posts.Title: Tests on Monday. This time feels different 1 2

Posts.Content: I think you should bring a tape recorder because it is hard to digest all the information, and you may mix up some of the things that are said to you. Or if you feel funny bringing one in with you, you could just bring a small notebook and jot down notes. Does the letter tell you why you are going to an oncologist at this point? I wish you luck, and hope that this doctor can help you, and start you on the road to recovery. Please keep us posted. I will be thinking about you! Love to you.
Posts.Title: Tests on Monday. This time feels different 1 2

Posts.Content: I am so sorry that you received bad news. Right now, you need to be biopsied, diagnosed and staged. I wish I could give you a hug right now, but please know that I am here for you. To give you some encouragement, I can tell you that I have known people who are in the exact situation you are in right now with the large chest mass, enlarged lymph nodes, have had treatment and are alive and well many years later. I know that not all illnesses are the same, but I am praying that you fall in the good category. If I can help in any way, just ask. Good luck to you, sweetie!
Posts.Title: Tests on Monday. This time feels different 1 2

Posts.Content: Good Luck! I will be thinking of you! Carm
Posts.Title: Tests on Monday. This time feels different 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi! About a year ago, I had an tiny suspicious area show up on a breast MRI that wasn't seen on a mammo or ultrasound. I had a biopsy under the MRI machine which showed severe atypia with cells that could potentially turn malignant at any time. Because the radiologist was unsure that all the cell were removed, I was advised to have a wide cut surgical biopsy to make sure all the cells were gone. I did that, and, thankfully, my results were benign. What I want to tell you, is that about 10 years ago, I had an area of calcifications that appeared to be benign, but because they were numerous in number, the area was questionable. I chose the 6 months wait and see instead of the surgical biopsy. During those 6 long months, I worried day and night each and every day. When I went for the mammo, the area was unchanged, but I chose to have the surgical biopsy just for my peace of mind. It turned out to be a papilloma which was a benign condition. The surgery was easy. I had to wear a bra day and night for a week. I couldn't take a shower for 2 days. I had very little discomfort-took only tylenol for pain. For your own peace of mind, do the surgery. If you have any questions, please ask me, and I will help you in any way I can. Good luck, sweetie!
Posts.Title: Excisional/surgical biopsies - Any advice?

Posts.Content: Hi I had a biopsy done under the ultrasound sound last Feb. It was done at a breast center in a hospital, and I was told the results one hour later. My results were abnormal cells, so I had a surgical biopsy done a week later. Thankfully, those results were benign. I just want to tell you that it is not a difficult or painful procedure. If you have any questions, please feel free to ask me. I wish you luck!
Posts.Title: Category 4 mammo US results
